nodes.text: The empirical and methodological contributions of David Card, Joshua Angrist, and Guido Imbens transformed applied microeconomics by centering research design and formalizing causal interpretation of natural experiments and instrumental variables

Design-based empirical approach: emphasize identifying the source of treatment variation, construct appropriate comparison groups, and make identifying assumptions transparent and testable where possible

The potential outcomes framework and the Local Average Treatment Effect (LATE) theorem formalize what IV estimates identify under assumptions of random assignment, exclusion, monotonicity, and relevance
Card pioneered large-scale natural experiment studies in labor economics that produced surprising causal evidence influencing theory and follow-up research
Angrist and Imbens developed methodological insights clarifying internal versus external validity of IV estimates, treatment effect heterogeneity, and when IV recovers effects for compliers (LATE)
Method: use of natural experiments and tailored data collection (e.g., field surveys, administrative linkages) to implement credible research designs when RCTs are infeasible
Assumption and limitation: design-based estimates can achieve internal validity but may have limited external validity and rely on institutional knowledge to assess identifying assumptions

Result: under the potential outcomes LATE assumptions, a binary-instrument IV estimand identifies the average treatment effect for compliers (those whose treatment is changed by the instrument), not necessarily the population average treatment effect
Implication: IV estimates reflect the source of variation used; narrow instruments (e.g., quarter-of-birth) identify effects for a small subpopulation and require caution when generalizing

Assumption: identification requires random or as-good-as-random instrument assignment, an exclusion restriction that the instrument affects outcomes only through treatment, monotonicity (no defiers), and relevance (nonzero first stage)
Evidence (Card) â€” Mariel boatlift: comparing Miami to similar cities before and after 1980 shows little effect of a large low-skill immigrant inflow on native wages and employment

Empirical evidence from landmark studies: (a) Card and Krueger 1992/1994 found no employment decline in NJ fast-food after a minimum wage increase, (b) Angrist and Krueger 1991 used quarter-of-birth IV to estimate a roughly 10% return to an additional year of schooling, (c) Angrist 1990 used draft lottery IV to estimate a negative earnings effect of military service (~15%), (d) Imbens, Rubin, Sacerdote 2001 found modest negative labor effects of unearned lottery income

Conclusion: The laureates strengthened empirical economics by promoting transparent research designs, clarifying IV interpretation, encouraging tailored data collection, and motivating follow-up work on heterogeneity, external validity, and structural extrapolation
